name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: ¿Para qué es esta función?

sideB.text: What is this function for?
What does this function do?
What is the purpose of this function?
What is this function used for?

cards.note:
**[111]**

Standard question structure: [Question Word] + [Auxiliary/Verb] + [Subject] + [Preposition]?

~For what is this function?~ (While grammatically possible, it sounds very formal or archaic. [What is this function for?] is the standard natural form.)

~What does this function for?~ (Incorrect: 'Does' requires a main verb like 'do'. Since the question uses the preposition 'for' to ask about purpose, use the verb [is]: 'What [is] this function for?')

~What does this function used for?~ (Incorrect: 'Used' is a past participle here requiring the passive voice auxiliary [is], not 'does'. Correct: 'What [is] this function used for?')

~What is meant to be this function?~ (Incorrect Word Order: This asks about identity, not purpose. Correct structure: 'What [is] this function [meant to be]?')

cards.sideA: No sé qué hace esta parte del código.

sideB.text: I don't know what this part of the code does.
I'm not sure what this code snippet is doing.
I have no idea what this section of code does.

cards.note:
**[63]**

Indirect Question Rule: Use statement order [Subject + Verb].

Correct: ...what this part [does].

~...what does this part~ (Incorrect: In embedded questions, do not use the auxiliary 'do/does' and do not invert the order. The subject 'this part' must come before the verb 'does'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuáles serían mis feriados legales?

sideB.text: What would be my legal holidays?
Which ones would be my statutory holidays?
What are my statutory holidays?
Which ones would be my legal holidays?

cards.note:
When choosing from a specific group (days in a calendar), [Which] or [Which ones] is precise.

Use [What] or [Which] for days.

~Which ones my legal holidays would be?~ (Incorrect Word Order: For questions, the verb comes before the subject: [would be my legal holidays].)

cards.sideA: Solo arreglé la indentación ahí.

sideB.text: I only fixed the indentation there.
I just corrected the indentation there.
I simply fixed the indentation in that part.
I just fixed the indentation there.

cards.note: [Indentation] refers to the space at the beginning of a line of code to indicate hierarchy.

cards.sideA: El cambio de lógica real está en la línea 45.

sideB.text: The actual logic change is in line 45.
The real logic change is on line 45.
The logic change itself is found on line 45.

cards.note:
Use preposition [in] or [on] for code lines.

~The actual logic change is at line 45~ (Less common, but understandable. [On line X] is preferred.)

~The real logic change is on the line 45~ (Incorrect: Do not use [the] before a number; say [Line 45].)

~The actual logic change is in the line 45~ (Incorrect: Remove [the].)

cards.sideA: Ahora inserta un salto de línea.

sideB.text: Now it inserts a line break.
Now it adds a newline.
It inserts a newline character now.
Now, insert a line break.

cards.note:
[Newline] or [Line break] are the technical terms for the character that moves the cursor to the next line.

~...insert a break line~ (Incorrect: The compound noun is [line break], not [break line].)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando el array en una tabla virtual.

sideB.text: We are parsing the array into a virtual table.
We're converting the array into a virtual table.
We are parsing the array to create a virtual table.

cards.note:
**[146]**

We generally say [parse into] when transforming data structure A to structure B.

~We are parsing the array in a virtual table~ (Incorrect: Use [into] for transformation.)

cards.sideA: Estamos parseando la lista en filas de SQL.

sideB.text: We are parsing the list into SQL rows.
We are converting the list into SQL rows.
We're transforming the list into SQL rows.

cards.note:
**[146]**

[Rows] refers specifically to horizontal records in a database table.

~We are parsing the list in SQL rows~ (Incorrect: Use [into] for transformation.)

cards.sideA: La variable está siendo convertida por Cast a otro tipo.

sideB.text: The variable is being cast to another type.
We are casting the variable to a different type.
The variable is being converted via Cast to another type.

cards.note:
In programming, [Cast] is used as a verb: 'To cast X to Y'.

~The variable is being cast into another type~ (Incorrect: Use [to] for type casting.)

~...parsed by cast...~ (Incorrect: [Parsing] (analyzing text) and [Casting] (converting types) are different operations. Use [converted] or just [cast].)

cards.sideA: Lo elegí al azar.

sideB.text: I chose it randomly.
I picked it at random.
I selected it randomly.

cards.note: [At random] and [Randomly] are interchangeable adverbs here.

cards.sideA: El valor por defecto de la columna de estado es 'Activo'.

sideB.text: The default value of the status column is 'Active'.
The status column's default value is 'Active'.
'Active' is the default value for the status column.
The default value of the state column is 'Active'.

cards.note:
[Default value] is the value a variable/column takes if none is specified.

~The defect value...~ (Incorrect: [Defect] means a flaw or bug. Use [Default] for a preset value.)

~The default value of the state of the column...~ (Too wordy. Use [Status column] or [Column status] for technical precision.)

cards.sideA: Si G es igual a 0, el resultado de NULLIF es NULL.

sideB.text: If G is equal to 0, the result of NULLIF is NULL.
If G equals 0, NULLIF returns NULL.
When G is 0, the result of NULLIF is NULL.

cards.note: [NULLIF(a,b)] is a SQL function that returns NULL if a equals b, otherwise it returns a.

cards.sideA: Estamos realizando manejo de nulos aquí.

sideB.text: We are performing null handling here.
We're handling nulls here.
We are doing null handling here.

cards.note: [Null handling] is the technique of safely managing potential null values.

cards.sideA: Es mejor que lo aprendas rápido.

sideB.text: You'd better learn it fast.
It's best if you learn it quickly.
You better learn it fast.
It's better you learn it fast.

cards.note:
**[37]**

To give strong advice or a warning (implying negative consequences if not followed), we use [You'd better] (contraction of 'You had better').

~It's better that you learn it~ (Grammatically valid but less idiomatic for direct advice. [It's best if...] is a good alternative.)

cards.sideA: Necesitamos ver cuál es el cuello de botella que retrasa el sistema.

sideB.text: We need to see what the bottleneck slowing down the system is.
We need to identify the bottleneck delaying the system.
We need to find out what bottleneck is holding up the system.
We need to see what the bottleneck delaying the system is.
We need to see which one the bottleneck that is delaying the system is.

cards.note:
A [Bottleneck] is a point of congestion in a system that slows down the overall process.

[Holding up] is a common phrasal verb for 'retrasando' or 'deteniendo' progress.

~...what is the bottleneck delaying the system~ (Incorrect Word Order: In embedded questions [statements], the verb must come after the subject: '...what the bottleneck... [is]'.)

~...which one is the bottleneck that is delaying the system~ (Incorrect Word Order: In a dependent clause within a statement, use subject-verb order: '...which one the bottleneck... [is]'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es el cuello de botella que retrasa el sistema?

sideB.text: What is the bottleneck slowing down the system?
Which bottleneck is delaying the system?
What is the bottleneck holding up the system?
What is the bottleneck that delays the system?
Which one is the bottleneck that delays the system?
What is the bottleneck?

cards.note:
We use [What] when asking about the nature of the bottleneck.

 We use [Which] if we are selecting from a known list of potential bottlenecks.

~Which one is the bottleneck that it delays the system?~ (Incorrect: Do not use the pronoun [it] after 'that', as 'that' already represents the bottleneck.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuál es la parte que más demora en cargar?

sideB.text: Which part takes the longest to load?
What part takes the most time to load?
Which part is taking the longest to load?
What part takes the longest to load?
Which one is the part that takes the longest to load.

cards.note:
**[102]**

For duration, we use the structure: [Takes] + [Time].

[The longest] is the most natural superlative for time duration.

~Which part delays more in load?~ (Incorrect: 'Delay' is usually transitive or implies lateness, not duration. Use [takes the longest].)

cards.sideA: Lo que más demora en cargar es...

sideB.text: What takes the longest to load is...
The part that takes the most time to load is...
What takes the most time to load is...
What takes the longest is...

cards.note:
**[102]**

This is a Noun Clause starting with [What] (Lo que).

~The which takes the longest~ (Incorrect: Never say 'The which'. Use [What] or [The thing that].)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué estás dispuesto a hacer?

sideB.text: What are you willing to do?
What are you prepared to do?
How far are you willing to go?

cards.note:
**[150]**

[To be willing to] means to be ready, eager, or prepared to do something (estar dispuesto).

~What are you disposed to do?~ (False Friend: 'Disposed' typically means 'inclined' or 'likely' [e.g., 'disposed to agree'], or 'arranged'. It is very formal and rarely used to mean 'willing' in this context.)

cards.sideA: Las mejoras del proceso no estaban ahí.

sideB.text: The process improvements weren't there.
The improvements to the process were not there.
The process enhancements weren't there.
The improvements of the process were not there.

cards.note:
[Improvements] or [Enhancements] are standard terms for 'mejoras'.

When using compound nouns, the singular acts as an adjective: [Process improvements] (not ~Processes improvements~).

~...weren't be there~ (Incorrect grammar: You cannot use 'were' and 'be' together like this. Use [weren't there].)

cards.sideA: Las fechas tentativas no las manejo yo.

sideB.text: I don't handle the tentative dates.
I don't manage the tentative dates.
The tentative dates aren't up to me.

cards.note:
[Tentative] means provisional or subject to change.

[To handle] is a very common verb for 'manejar' in the sense of dealing with or controlling a situation/task.

[Not up to me] is an idiomatic way to say it is not your decision or responsibility.

cards.sideA: Viene directo en el array.

sideB.text: It comes directly in the array.
It comes straight from the array.
It is found directly in the array.
It comes in the array directly.

cards.note: [Straight from] implies without intermediate steps.

cards.sideA: Itera por los valores y los suma.

sideB.text: It iterates through the values and sums them up.
It loops through the values and adds them.
It iterates over the values and sums them.
It iterates through the values and adds them.

cards.note:
We say [iterate through] or [iterate over] a list/array.

[Sum up] is the phrasal verb for calculating the total.

~...and then adding them~ (Incorrect grammar: Parallel structure is required. 'Iterates' (verb) ... 'adds' (verb).)

cards.sideA: Los detalles de precios están destinados a mostrar los ajustes de precios.

sideB.text: The pricing details are meant to display price adjustments.
The pricing details are intended to show price adjustments.
The pricing details are designed to display price adjustments.
The pricing details are meant to show the adjustment prices.

cards.note:
**[147]**

[Be meant to] is an excellent phrase for 'Estar destinado a', 'Tener el propósito de', or 'Se supone que'.

[Pricing] refers to the structure/strategy of prices, while [Price] refers to the value itself.

cards.sideA: Este campo tiene el propósito de capturar el email principal del usuario.

sideB.text: This field is meant to capture the user's primary email address.
This field is intended to capture the user's main email address.
The purpose of this field is to capture the user's primary email.
This field is meant to capture the main user's email.

cards.note:
**[147]**

Use [meant to] or [intended to] for functionality goals.

[Primary] is more formal and technical than 'Main' in database contexts.

[Capture] is the standard industry verb for getting input from a user.

~...the main email of the user~ (Unnatural: For people and users, we prefer the possessive 's: [the user's email].)

cards.sideA: La columna UNIT_LIST_PRICE está destinada a contener el precio sin ajustes.

sideB.text: The UNIT LIST PRICE column is meant to hold the non-adjusted price.
The UNIT LIST PRICE column is intended to contain the unadjusted price.
The UNIT_LIST_PRICE column is meant to store the price without adjustments.

cards.note:
**[147]**

Database columns [hold] or [store] data.

[Non-adjusted] or [Unadjusted] are precise technical terms.

cards.sideA: La función totalAdjustmentIncrement() tiene el propósito de calcular la suma.

sideB.text: The totalAdjustmentIncrement function is meant to calculate the sum.
The totalAdjustmentIncrement  function is intended to compute the sum.
The purpose of the totalAdjustmentIncrement() function is to calculate the sum.
The totalAdjustmentIncrement function is meant to calculate the addition.

cards.note:
**[147]**

Again, [is meant to] is the most natural way to describe what a function is supposed to do.

~...has the purpose of calculate...~ (Incorrect: After prepositions like 'of', you must use the gerund [-ing]: 'purpose of calculating'. Also, 'is meant to' is more natural than 'has the purpose'.)

cards.sideA: Todo este módulo está destinado a ser compatible con iOS 13.0 en adelante.

sideB.text: This entire module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 and above.
This whole module is intended to support iOS 13.0 and later.
This module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 onwards.
All of this module is meant to be compatible with iOS 13.0 and above.

cards.note:
**[147]**

For versions, we use [and above], [and later], or [onwards] to express 'en adelante'.

~...iOS 13.0 in forward~ (Incorrect literal translation.)

~All this module...~ (Incorrect: 'All' requires 'of' or 'the' in this structure: 'All of this module' or 'The whole module'. [This entire module] is more precise.)

cards.sideA: Lo que más me gusta es la simplicidad.

sideB.text: What I like the most is the simplicity.
The thing I like most is the simplicity.
What I like best is the simplicity.

cards.note:
**[149]**

This is a Noun Clause starting with [What] (Lo que).

Structure: [What] + [Subject] + [Verb] + [is]...

~What the most I like...~ (Incorrect: The word order is [What] + [Subject] + [Verb] + [Adverb]. Example: 'What I like most'.)

cards.sideA: Lo que menos me gusta es la falta de documentación.

sideB.text: What I like the least is the lack of documentation.
The thing I like least is the lack of documentation.
What I dislike the most is the lack of documentation.

cards.note:
**[149]**

For 'Lo que menos...', we use [What I like the least] or we switch the verb to [What I dislike the most].

~What I less like...~ (Incorrect: [Less] is for comparisons (2 things). For 'lo que menos', use the superlative [Least] or [Dislike the most].)

cards.sideA: Lo que más pesa son los archivos de video.

sideB.text: What takes up the most space are the video files.
The heaviest files are the video files.
What uses the most storage are the video files.
What weighs the most are the video files.

cards.note:
**[149]**

While [heaviest] is technically correct, in digital contexts we often talk about what [takes up space] or [uses storage].

~What weights the most...~ (Incorrect: [Weight] is a noun. The verb is [Weigh]. Correct: 'What [weighs] the most'.)

~What weight the most...~ (Incorrect verb conjugation.)

cards.sideA: Lo que más toma tiempo es el envío de los datos.

sideB.text: What takes the longest is sending the data.
The most time-consuming part is the data transmission.
What takes the most time is sending the data.

cards.note:
**[149]**

[Takes the longest] is the most natural way to express maximum duration.

[Time-consuming] is a great adjective for 'algo que toma mucho tiempo'.

~What takes most time...~ (Incorrect: Superlatives require the definite article: 'What takes [the] most time'.)

~What takes the longest is the sending data~ (Incorrect: Use 'is sending data' or 'is the sending of data'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo sería eso?

sideB.text: What would that look like?
How would that work?
What would that be like?
How would it be?
How would that be?

cards.note:
When asking for a description or an explanation of a concept/process, [What would that look like?] is very common in business/tech contexts.

~How would be that?~ (Incorrect structure. Subject [that] must come after the auxiliary [would].)

~How would it be that?~ (Incorrect structure. 'That' is the subject, so it cannot be placed at the end if 'it' is also used as a dummy subject in this way.)

cards.sideA: Eso sería como un reinicio forzado.

sideB.text: That would be like a hard reset.
It would be similar to a forced reboot.
That would look like a hard reset.
That would be like a force restart.

cards.note: Use [be like] to make comparisons.

cards.sideA: abs() significa valor absoluto.

sideB.text: abs() stands for absolute value.
abs() means absolute value.
The function abs() represents absolute value.

cards.note:
When explaining abbreviations or acronyms, [stands for] is the precise verb.

Example: HTML [stands for] HyperText Markup Language.

cards.sideA: La función abs() siempre devuelve un número positivo.

sideB.text: The abs() function always returns a positive number.
abs() always returns a positive value.
The abs() function always yields a positive number.

cards.note:
In programming, functions [return] values.

~...comes back a number...~ (Incorrect: Use [returns].)

cards.sideA: Si el número es positivo, abs() no lo cambia.

sideB.text: If the number is positive, abs() doesn't change it.
If the number is positive, abs() leaves it unchanged.
For positive numbers, abs() makes no changes.

cards.note: [Leaves it unchanged] is a very elegant way to say 'no lo cambia'.

cards.sideA: Si el número es negativo, abs() elimina el signo.

sideB.text: If the number is negative, abs() removes the sign.
If the number is negative, abs() strips the sign.
For negative numbers, abs() gets rid of the sign.

cards.note:
**[65]**

[Strips] is a technical verb often used for removing characters or formatting.

[Get rid of] is a common phrasal verb for 'eliminar/deshacerse de'.

~...abs() deletes the sign~ (Unnatural: 'Delete' usually implies erasing a file or an object. For values or properties, we use [removes], [strips], or [drops].)

cards.sideA: Una vez resolvamos el problema, podremos crear un nuevo release.

sideB.text: Once we solve the problem, we can create a new release.
As soon as we fix the issue, we'll be able to cut a new release.
Once the issue is resolved, we can generate a new release.

cards.note:
Time Clause Rule: After [Once], [When], or [As soon as] referring to the future, use the **Present Tense**.

~Once we will solve...~ (Incorrect: Never use 'will' immediately after 'Once' in this context.)

[Cut a release] is common industry slang for creating a specific version.

cards.sideA: No quiero hacerlos perder el tiempo.

sideB.text: I don't want to waste your time.
I don't want to take up too much of your time.
I don't want to make you lose time.
I don't want you to waste your time.

cards.note:
[Waste time] implies using it unproductively.

[Take up time] implies occupying someone's schedule.

~Make you lose time~ (Understandable, but [waste your time] is the standard phrase.)

~I don't want to you waste...~ (Grammar Error: 'Want' is followed by Object + Infinitive: 'I don't want [you] [to waste]'.)

cards.sideA: No quiero cagarla.

sideB.text: I don't want to screw it up.
I don't want to mess it up.
I don't want to drop the ball.

cards.note:
[Screw up] and [Mess up] are common informal phrasal verbs for making a mistake ('cagarla'/'arruinarla').

[Drop the ball] is a business idiom meaning to fail in a responsibility.

cards.sideA: Sorry, estoy activando los captions.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm turning on the captions.
Sorry, I'm enabling the captions.
Apologies, I'm just switching on the closed captions.
Sorry, I'm activating the captions.

cards.note: Use [turn on], [switch on], or [enable] for features/settings.

cards.sideA: Sí, son súper útiles para mí los captions.

sideB.text: Yeah, captions are super useful for me.
Yes, captions are really helpful to me.
Yeah, I find captions very useful.

cards.note: [Helpful] and [Useful] are generally interchangeable here.

cards.sideA: Perdona, estoy algo perdido.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm a bit lost.
Excuse me, I'm a little lost.
Sorry, I'm not following.
Sorry, I'm a bit confused.

cards.note: [I'm not following] is a professional way to say you don't understand the current explanation.

cards.sideA: Perdona, estoy algo perdido en esta materia.

sideB.text: Sorry, I'm a bit lost on this subject.
Sorry, I'm a little out of my depth here.
Excuse me, I'm not very familiar with this topic.
Sorry, I'm a bit lost on this matter.

cards.note: [Out of my depth] is an idiom meaning the topic is too advanced or difficult for your current knowledge.

cards.sideA: Necesito actualizar algunas filas del excel.

sideB.text: I need to update a few rows in the Excel file.
I need to update some rows in the spreadsheet.
I have to update a few rows in the sheet.

cards.note: [Spreadsheet] is the generic technical term for Excel/Google Sheets files.

cards.sideA: Si tuviese una reunión uno a uno, sería más sencillo.

sideB.text: If I had a one-on-one meeting, it would be simpler.
It would be easier if I had a one-on-one.
If I were in a one-on-one meeting, it would be easier.

cards.note:
**[9]**

Second Conditional: [If] + [Past Simple], ... [Would] + [Verb].

[One-on-one] (often written 1:1) is the standard term for a meeting between two people.

~If I had a meeting one-on-one...~ (Unnatural Word Order: Adjectives usually come before the noun in English: [a one-on-one meeting].)

cards.sideA: El problema ahora es este servicio que lo está arruinando todo.

sideB.text: The problem right now is this service that's messing everything up.
The issue now is this service that is ruining everything.
The problem is this service is screwing everything up.
The problem now is this service that is messing everything up.

cards.note: [Messing up] is informal but very common for 'arruinando' or 'desordenando'.

cards.sideA: Esto lo está arruinando todo.

sideB.text: This is ruining everything.
This is messing everything up.
This is throwing a wrench in the works.
This is messing up everything.

cards.note: [Throwing a wrench in the works] is an idiom for when something suddenly disrupts a plan or process.

cards.sideA: Tuvimos un retroceso.

sideB.text: We had a setback.
We hit a snag.
We experienced a setback.

cards.note:
[Setback] is the professional term for a reversal in progress ('retroceso').

[Hit a snag] implies encountering a small, unexpected problem.

~We had a stepback~ (Incorrect: Use [setback] for progress reversal. A 'step back' is a physical move or a strategic retreat.)

cards.sideA: Tuvimos un retroceso en ese tema.

sideB.text: We had a setback on that issue.
We faced a setback regarding that topic.
We hit a snag on that matter.

cards.note:
We typically use the preposition [on] or [with] when talking about setbacks in specific areas.

~We had a delay~ (Nuance: A [delay] means time was lost. A [setback] implies progress was lost or a new problem appeared.)

~We had a step back~ (Incorrect: [Step back] usually refers to physically moving back or gaining perspective. The noun for 'contratiempo' is [setback].)

cards.sideA: Lo que menos me gusta es la falta de puntualidad.

sideB.text: What I like the least is the lack of punctuality.
The thing I like least is the lack of punctuality.
What I dislike the most is the lack of punctuality.

cards.note:
**[149]**

For "Lo que menos...", we use the structure [What I like the least...].

Alternatively, you can switch the verb to the opposite ([dislike]) and use [the most].

cards.sideA: Lo que menos quiero es hacer eso.

sideB.text: What I want the least is to do that.
The last thing I want is to do that.
What I want least of all is to do that.

cards.note:
**[149]**

Note that after [want] (a verb of intent), we use the **Infinitive** ([to do]), not the Gerund.

[The last thing I want] is a very common idiom to express strong reluctance ("lo último que quiero").

cards.sideA: Las reglas serán destacadas en color rojo.

sideB.text: The rules will be highlighted in red.
The rules will be marked in red.
Rules will be featured in red color.
The rules will be highlighted in red color.

cards.note:
Use [highlighted] when referring to visual emphasis in UI/UX.

~The rules will be bolded in red~ (Incorrect: 'Bolded' refers to thickness, not necessarily color. Use [highlighted] or [marked].)

cards.sideA: Se destacarán en rojo, en caso de no cumplirse las reglas.

sideB.text: They will be highlighted in red if the rules are not met.
They will stand out in red in case of non-compliance.
These will be shown in red if the rules are violated.
They will be highlighted in red in case of not meeting the rules.

cards.note:
To [meet the rules] or [meet requirements] is the standard professional way to say 'cumplir'.

~In case of not comply~ (Incorrect Grammar: After 'of', you must use a noun or gerund: 'of [non-compliance]' or 'of [not complying]').

~They will be highlighted in red in case of the rules are not met.~ (Incorrect: [In case of] must be followed by a noun or gerund, not a full clause. Use 'in case the rules are not met'.)

~It will be highlighted in red in case of not meeting the rules~ (Incorrect: Use 'They' to match the plural subject.)

cards.sideA: El precio se calcula según lo que cueste el producto el día que se entrega.

sideB.text: The price is calculated based on the product cost on the delivery day.
The price is determined by the product's value on the day it is delivered.
The price is calculated according to the product cost at the time of delivery.

cards.note:
[Based on] and [According to] are perfect for 'según'.

~Calculated like the cost~ (Unnatural: Use [based on] for calculations.)

cards.sideA: El precio se calcula según lo que cuesta el producto el día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The price is calculated based on the product cost on the day the order is placed.
Pricing is based on the cost at the time the order is made.
The price depends on the product cost on the ordering date.

cards.note:
[To place an order] is the specific collocation for 'hacer un pedido'.

~On the day the order is done~ (Unnatural: We 'place' or 'make' orders, we don't 'do' them.)

cards.sideA: Eso tomaría un poco más de tiempo.

sideB.text: That would take a bit more time.
That would take a little longer.
That might take some extra time.
That would take a little more time.
That would take a little bit more time.

cards.note:
Use [would] for the conditional 'tomaría'.

[A little longer] is the most idiomatic way to express 'un poco más de tiempo'.

~That would take a little bit of more time.~ (Incorrect: Remove [of] in this structure. Use 'a little bit more time'.)

cards.sideA: Sean cambió este código.

sideB.text: Sean changed this code.
Sean modified this code.
Sean made changes to this code.

cards.note: Standard Past Simple. Use [modified] for a more formal/technical tone.

cards.sideA: Fue Sean quien cambió este código.

sideB.text: It was Sean who changed this code.
Sean was the one who modified this code.
It was Sean that made the changes to this code.

cards.note:
This is a Cleft Sentence (It was X who...). It is used to provide emphasis on the person.

~He was Sean who...~ (Incorrect: Use [It was] to introduce the subject of emphasis.)

~Sean was who changed this code.~ (Incorrect: Needs a noun/pronoun before 'who'. Use 'Sean was [the one] who'.)

cards.sideA: Eso me tomaría un poco más de tiempo.

sideB.text: That would take me a bit more time.
It would take me a little longer.
That might take me some additional time.
That would take me more time.

cards.note:
When specifying the person, the object pronoun [me] goes between the verb and the time: [take me] + [time].

~That would take to me...~ (Incorrect: Do not use 'to' with the verb 'take' in this context.)

~That would take me a little bit of more time~ (Incorrect: Remove [of]. Use 'a little bit more time'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto tomaría eso?

sideB.text: How long would that take?
How much time would that take?
How long might that take?
How long would it take?

cards.note:
**[102]**

Use [How long] for duration. 

~How much would that take?~ (Ambiguous: This sounds like you are asking about cost/quantity, not time duration.)

cards.sideA: Por ahora no tengo una respuesta para eso.

sideB.text: I don't have an answer for that right now.
For the time being, I don't have an answer for that.
I don't have an answer to that at the moment.
For now I don't have an answer for that.

cards.note:
[For the time being] and [Right now] are common phrases for 'por ahora'.

~I don't have now an answer for that~ (Incorrect: Adverb placement. Use 'I don't have an answer for that [now]'.)

cards.sideA: Puedo trabajar en ello, crearé una task.

sideB.text: I can work on it; I'll create a task.
I can look into that and set up a ticket.
I can handle it; I'll open a task for it.

cards.note:
[I'll] (I will) for spontaneous decisions or promises. 

[Ticket] is often used instead of 'task' in Jira/ServiceNow environments.

cards.sideA: Nunca he visto algo sobre eso.

sideB.text: I've never seen anything about that.
I haven't seen anything regarding that before.
I've never come across anything like that.

cards.note:
Use [Present Perfect] (I have seen) for experiences. 

[Come across] is a phrasal verb meaning to find or see something by chance.

~I've never seen something about that~ (Incorrect: In negative sentences or Present Perfect experiences, use [anything] instead of 'something'.)

cards.sideA: Echaré un vistazo en eso, y te haré saber.

sideB.text: I'll take a look at that and let you know.
I'll look into it and get back to you.
I'll check that out and keep you posted.

cards.note:
Professional collocations: [Let you know], [Get back to you], [Keep you posted].

[Look into it] is more formal than 'take a look'.

~I'll take a look on that~ (Incorrect: The fixed preposition for this expression is [take a look at] something.)

~I'll take a look at that and I let you know~ (Incorrect: Tense mismatch. Use '...and [let] you know' or '...and [I will] let you know'.)

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time.
It's only a matter of time.
It's simply a question of time.

cards.note: [A matter of time] is the fixed idiomatic expression for 'cosa de tiempo'.

cards.sideA: Es solo cosa de tiempo para que ocurra.

sideB.text: It's just a matter of time before it happens.
It's only a matter of time until it occurs.
It is just a matter of time for it to happen.

cards.note:
Notice the use of [before] or [until] after the expression to indicate the event.

~It is matter of time~ (Incorrect: Needs the article [a matter of time]).

~It's just a matter of time to happen.~ (Incorrect: Use [before] it happens or 'for it to happen'.)

~It's just a matter of time that it happens~ (Incorrect: Use [before] or [until] instead of 'that' in this idiom.)

cards.sideA: Lo siento, no tengo ningún archivo adjunto.

sideB.text: I'm sorry, I don't have any attachments.
Sorry, I don't have any attached files.
I'm sorry, there are no files attached.

cards.note:
Use [Attachments] or [Attached files] for documents sent along with a message.

~I don't have any adjunt file~ (Incorrect: 'Adjunt' is not an English word. Use the past participle [Attached].)

cards.sideA: Al revisar el código para la visualización del catálogo, he encontrado ...

sideB.text: While reviewing the code for the catalog display, I found...
Upon reviewing the code for the catalog view, I've found...
While checking the catalog visualization code, I discovered...

cards.note:
[While reviewing] or [Upon reviewing] are professional ways to introduce an action performed during another activity.

[Display], [View], and [Visualization] are common terms for 'visualización' in UI contexts.

cards.sideA: No estoy seguro de cuál es el comportamiento esperado para el catálogo.

sideB.text: I'm not sure what the expected behavior is for the catalog.
I'm uncertain about the expected behavior of the catalog.
I don't know what the intended behavior for the catalog is.

cards.note:
In technical English, [Behavior] refers to how a system or component functions.

Indirect Question Rule: The verb [is] goes at the end of the clause: '...what the expected behavior [is]'.

cards.sideA: No tengo que cambiar nada, a no ser que me lo pidan.

sideB.text: I don't have to change anything unless I'm asked to.
I don't need to change anything unless requested.
I am not to change anything unless I am told to.

cards.note:
[Unless] means 'except if'. It is often followed by a passive structure like [unless I am asked].

~Unless they ask to me~ (Incorrect: 'Ask' does not take 'to' before the person. Correct: 'Unless they ask me'.)

cards.sideA: A no ser que me lo pidan, no debo cambiar nada.

sideB.text: Unless I'm asked, I shouldn't change anything.
Unless requested, I must not change anything.
Unless I am told otherwise, I won't change anything.

cards.note:
[Shouldn't] indicates it is not advisable. [Must not] indicates a prohibition or strict rule.

[Unless told otherwise] is a very common professional phrase meaning 'a menos que se me diga lo contrario'.

cards.sideA: No he hecho este código en absoluto.

sideB.text: I didn't write this code at all.
I haven't written this code whatsoever.
I didn't create this code at all.

cards.note:
[At all] and [Whatsoever] are used at the end of negative sentences to add emphasis.

~I haven't made this code~ (In coding, we usually [write], [create], or [develop] code rather than 'make' it.)

cards.sideA: Esa rama es la que tiene cambios que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That branch is the one with the changes we need to pull.
That branch has the changes we need to bring in.
That's the branch that contains the changes we need to merge.

cards.note: In Git terminology, [Pull], [Bring in], or [Merge] are used for bringing changes from one branch to another.

cards.sideA: Esa tabla es la que tiene datos que necesitamos traer.

sideB.text: That table is the one with the data we need to fetch.
That table has the data we need to pull.
That's the table containing the data we need to bring over.

cards.note:
For databases, [Fetch] is the standard verb for retrieving data.

~That table is who has~ (Incorrect: Use [which] or [that] for objects like tables, never 'who'.)

cards.sideA: El codigo entrante a la izquierda.

sideB.text: The incoming code is on the left.
The incoming code is positioned on the left side.
The left side shows the incoming code.

cards.note:
In merge tools, [Incoming] refers to the changes coming from another branch/source.

Use the preposition [on] for sides: [on the left], [on the right].

cards.sideA: El codigo entrante es el nuevo que viene.

sideB.text: The incoming code is the new one coming in.
Incoming code refers to the new changes.
The code coming in is the new version.

cards.note: [Incoming] is the technical term for the 'entrante' code in a conflict resolution tool.

cards.sideA: El codigo actual a la derecha.

sideB.text: The current code is on the right.
The current code is positioned to the right.
The right side shows the current code.

cards.note: [Current] refers to the code in your local branch where you are merging into.

cards.sideA: El codigo de la derecha es de la rama actual.

sideB.text: The code on the right is from the current branch.
The right-side code belongs to the current branch.
The code to the right represents the current branch.

cards.note: When comparing code in a diff viewer, we use [on the right] to locate the local version.

cards.sideA: El panel inferior es el resultado de ambos.

sideB.text: The bottom panel is the result of both.
The lower panel shows the outcome of both.
The panel at the bottom is the combined result.

cards.note: [Bottom] or [Lower] panel refers to the merge editor's result area.

cards.sideA: Por lo general el entrante tiene prioridad en el actual.

sideB.text: Usually, the incoming code takes priority over the current one.
Generally, incoming changes override the current code.
The incoming code typically has precedence over the existing one.

cards.note:
[Takes priority over] and [Has precedence over] are formal ways to say one thing is more important.

[Override] is a specific technical verb for one piece of code replacing another.

cards.sideA: Debemos presionar 'completar' por cada archivo.

sideB.text: We must press 'complete' for each file.
We have to click 'complete' for every file.
We need to hit 'complete' on every single file.

cards.note:
Use [Every] or [Each] for individuals in a group.

[Hit] is a common informal synonym for 'press' or 'click' a button.

cards.sideA: Baja un poco ese panel para ver los otros.

sideB.text: Move that panel down a bit to see the others.
Lower that panel slightly to view the rest.
Pull that panel down a little to see the other items.

cards.note:
[Move down], [Lower], or [Pull down] are used for UI elements.

[A bit], [Slightly], and [A little] are all used for 'un poco'.

cards.sideA: Sube un poco ese panel para verlo completo.

sideB.text: Move that panel up a bit to see it fully.
Raise that panel slightly to see the whole thing.
Push that panel up a little to see the full view.

cards.note: [Move up], [Raise], or [Push up] are the counterparts for moving elements upwards.

cards.sideA: Conserva lo que tienes ahi, no lo borres.

sideB.text: Keep what you have there; don't delete it.
Hold on to what you've got there; do not erase it.
Save what is there; don't wipe it out.

cards.note:
[Hold on to] is a phrasal verb meaning to keep something.

[Wipe out] is a phrasal verb meaning to completely erase or delete.

cards.sideA: No he dicho eso en 2 meses y medio atras.

sideB.text: I haven't said that in two and a half months.
It's been two and a half months since I said that.
I haven't said that since two and a half months ago.

cards.note:
When using [Ago] (atrás), we usually use the Past Simple: 'I said that 2 months ago'.

When using [Haven't said] (Present Perfect), we use [In] or [For] to show duration: 'I haven't said that [in] 2 months'.

~I haven't said that 2 months back~ (Unnatural: Use [ago] or duration with 'in/for'.)

cards.sideA: No he usado eso en 3 meses y medio atras.

sideB.text: I haven't used that in three and a half months.
I haven't used that since three and a half months ago.
The last time I used that was three and a half months ago.

cards.note:
Duration with Present Perfect: [Haven't used] + [in] + time.

[Three and a half] is the standard way to express '3 y medio'.

cards.sideA: El día que se hace el pedido.

sideB.text: The day the order is placed.
The date the order is made.
The day of the order placement.

cards.note:
[To place an order] is the idiomatic technical term for 'hacer un pedido'.

~The day the order is done~ (Incorrect: We don't 'do' orders. We [place] or [make] them.)
